content.description:
Follow the angling ledges right of

Peaches and Scream

.  Once on the tier follow the path of least resistance to the top.  I find going left of the crack on face holds then moving to the crack works best.  Note: The 5.4 + rating is given since this route isn't quite 5.5- but is definitely harder than a meek 5.4.

The route starts on the ledges just left of the trees on the right side.
content.protection: The pro isn't great and is hard to find so is not for new leaders.  Use anyone of the various bolts on top for the anchor.  Note! Many of these are manky and are not to be trusted.

content.description: Start in the right-facing dihedral and stem up high.  Undercling and reach high for a small pocket.  Finish with another reach for a higher pocket. This is a pretty fun sequence of moves.
content.protection:
Use the tree on top with a few long slings.

There are two bolts with chains on top of this climb.

content.description:
This route lies to the left of

Licorice Stick

. Start at the thin vertical seam 5 feet off the ground. If you actually start this, head towards the left-facing corner.
content.protection: Gear.
content.location:
This is right of

Pretzel Logic

and left of

Licorice Stick

.  Downclimb the chimney to the south of Grocery Store Walls.

content.description:
Look for some small ledges to the right of

Rat's Nest

. The start is where the 5.10 is. Pull up onto the 5 foot shelf using a few face holds and a weak sidepull. Follow ledges to the top.
content.protection: Toprope. Bring gear for an anchor.
content.location: Downclimb the chimney to the left of the Grocery Store Wall.

content.description:
Climb the offwidth, which is actually fun. I give it a 5+ rating for the OW. ;-)

This route is located by taking the Climber's Trail to the Grocery Store Wall, then hiking North along the base of the rock to the very end of the wall.  The routes on this face are all North-facing.
content.protection: Several cams up to 4" and some Aliens or tri-cams for pockets on the face.

content.description:
Start up the face of a short flake before you start into the crack, or just scramble up the side of the flake ramp. Climb a short crack section with good pro, and top out after the crux. Be careful of sleeping bats. It is possible to walk off here or build a TR anchor with pieces up to 4" in the crack.

Just like most of Castlewood, this is a short but fun route that may or may not have seen previous ascents. If you have any info regarding this route (name, FA,

etc

.), please feel free to contact me.
content.protection: Finger/hand-sized gear and up to 4" for a TR anchor.
content.location:
This is the obvious short crack just to the right of

Banana Chimney

.

content.description:
Climb the arete to the left of

Petrified Turd

corner crack. A short route considering a rather difficult anchor setup. It's better to combine it along with

Cactus Flower

to the left, the pendulum off

Cactus Flower

is rather entertaining, when you set up over Shake and Bake. When you finish the route, your head is three feet from the bee hive.
content.protection:
A beekeeper's suit may be a good idea in the summer, or at least throw one of those smoking teapots on your rack.

Gear and Runners bring a #5 cam if you've got it.
content.location: Access the top via the chimney down the trail to the left.

content.description: Climb the face through the concave scoop.  Look for an old 1/4" part way up.  Some hard stemming/smearing is the crux.  Stay in the trough the whole way up.
content.protection:
Use the same tree as

Teething Biscuit

for a TR.

There are two bolts with chains just to the right of the top of this climb.

content.description: Heading north from the climbers' trail junction with the cliff locate a crack with a pocket/ hole a few moves off the deck.  The first move is tricky to figure out but after that you climb up through the pocket and crack with a great nut placement at the top of the first crack.  Pick your own line from here, with many variations possible.  The last move off the ledge to the top is a face move to the bolts.
content.protection: Nuts, cams to #3 or 4, Hexes, slings to set up anchor.  There are bolts on top.

content.description:
This has a nice balance sequence right before the TR anchors.  There is not much for hands on it, but there is a solid right foot balanced by an interesting undercling.  It is a fun little route!

This route starts below the ledge about 8' up, then more or less follows the fall line of the rope from the anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt with hanger, 1 bolt with a removed hanger.  Long slings helpful.  Back up the 1 bolt with a #2 cam and a long sling.
content.location: This route is on the last east-facing section at the north terminus of the Grocery Store Wall.  If you turn and begin heading west, you've missed it.

content.description:
Just right of the five bolt route (

Bozo No No

) on the Grocery Store Walls, climb this fine route.  Start below the thin crack and climb up to it, using mostly face holds the whole route.  Finish to the double bolts or straight above the crack.

(The climb is on the wall just left of this picture.)
content.protection:
Pro seems to be discontinuous and tricky on this route.  A runout gains the crack and the crack ends below the top.  This route can be easily toproped on the adjacent double bolts without too much of a pendulum.

There is now a 2 bolt anchor with chains on top of this route.

content.description:
This route follows the face to the right of

Rain Dance Crack

.  It is tempting to go to the crack sometimes, but persevere and stay to the right.  Climb into the big cave pocket at the top for a rest and finish the route right below the bolts.  (Finish with

Rain Dance Crack

).
content.protection:
Use the two bolts on top of

Rain Dance Crack

.

content.description:
This route is around the corner south of

Petrified Turd

.  It can be identified by the large U-shaped trough about 25 feet up and a chalked undercling crack near the base.  The route starts on in the crack and a crimp to the right and moves up the chalked holds to the small cobbles and over the ledge.
content.protection: To top rope this, you need mid-sized cams or tri-cams and long slings.  The best way to do it is to set up the anchors one ledge below the top of the cliff.  If bouldering (not recomended), you need a pad and 2 spotters due to fall potential into a tree.

content.description:
This climb starts about 20 feet right of

Rat's Nest

. Start below and right of a large concavity about 10 feet up. Angle right around the concavity and follow pockets and ledges to the top. It looked like this route was bolted at some point and then chopped.
content.protection: There's a bolt up top, add some pro and go!
content.location: Downclimb the chimney south of Grocery Store Wall.

content.description: Begin at a left-facing dihedral.  Move to the right at the horizontal crack and finish on the middle of the face on column #2.
content.protection:
There is only one 1/4" bolt on top.

Eds. There is a 2 bolt anchor now.

content.description:
A short crack left of

Hot Fudge

that is completely filled with guano--very unappealing.  Let's just say this--there are some routes that were never meant to be climbed....
content.protection: Wide crack from 2-4".

content.description:
The climb starts easy and warms you up before you get to a small overhang. Mantel and look for the jugs above. Continue on the face, then finish to the canyon edge right above.

I would wish that I was the FA, but chances are someone climbed it before me. It's not bolted, not in any guidebooks, and very overgrown with vegetation. If you have any info, message me.
content.protection: There are no bolted anchors at the top. I found it best to make an anchor using natural features and static line. Watch out for sharp canyon edges and rope drag.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Blood Pudding

There is a small social trail that heads (left) to the base of

Meat Market

, there is a scrub oak bush in the way of the base. We found it easiest to belay from the trail or a brush clearing further down the trail.

THERE ARE NO BOLTED ANCHORS!!! I found it useful to bring at least a 30 foot static line to make a decent natural anchor for a toprope.

climbs.name: Pecan Pie
climbs.fa: from Tom Hansen's Climber's Guide to Castlewood

content.description:
Use the same start as

Rainbow Bread

, but angle right and up the corner.  It is easier than

Rainbow Bread

.
content.protection: TR- one bolt on top as of summer 2009, with good crack for backup pro.

content.description:
About ten feet right of

Hot Fudge

is a large flake on the ground.  Start right of this flake and climb up to a flake about 15' up.  Climb this flake to the ledge above and get on the big ledge.  You can finish with a direct finish on a nice face to bolts above if you're toproping or are willing to run it out.  The other finish traverses on the ledge left to an obvious weakness in the cliff.  Protect the crack and climb up it (harder) or climb a few moves on the face on the left.
content.protection:
Standard rack and slings.

There is a 2 bolt anchor on top of this route.

content.description:
Start on the face of a flake to a large alcove in the wall, then move up to an overhang. Once past the overhang, the fun starts. There is a rock projection from the wall. Mantel, then finish with another cruxy move to the anchor.

This climb is not in Tom Hanson's guidebook or any other guidebook I have seen. If someone has info on this climb (FA, name, dates, etc.), please let me know.

That being said, my group of climbing buddies have grown to know this climb as "Meat Market".
content.protection: A pair of bolted anchors.
content.location:
The climb is located on the wall to the right of

Blood Pudding

, accessed by a small social trail formed (left) toward the wall, from the main hiking trail. The climb starts in the first main clearing along social trail, to the left of a flake feature, up to a small overhang. Get to the canyon rim via access trail to the North (or any other scramble) to set up an anchor.

content.description: Climb the face up to the black, wet, left-facing dihedral.  This is a major water runoff whenever it has rained or snow is melting.  If you can find it dry, it's a great steep route with as many face holds as jamming.
content.protection: Cams in the finger-hand size.

content.description:
The route is listed in Hanson's old guidebook as 5.9+. It seems to have been lost in obscurity for quite some time now. I spent an hour scrubbing lichen and sweeping pine needles off and brought this little gem back to life!

The initial boulder problem is the crux, and it's possible that something down low has broken since the FA. A crashpad is the best protection for this section. The crack (and the pro) starts about 15 feet off the ground. A couple pads and a couple pieces makes for a fun, gritstone style route.
content.protection:
A couple small nuts and cams and crashpad(s).

The best anchor option is using a static rope from a tree 50 feet back from the cliff's edge.
content.location: Furthest left line on the G Store, 20 feet right of the access chimney.

content.description:
As

Hot Fudge

is generally described as a traverse from under

Donut Hole

, this line runs from directly under the crack. There are one or two nice jugs at the start which lead into a very small pinch and a great lunge to the left. That is definitely the crux and makes this line significantly harder. This then leads into the

Hot Fudge

crack, which I would rate an 8-. Nice climb.
content.protection: TR or  2 - #1 Camalots, 1 - 8 hexcentric, 1- size 12 BD nut.

content.description:
To the left of

Hamburger

is Hamburger Helper. Look for a small cave, from here climb up to a small ledge under a small notch (crux). Continue up the notch to easier terrain.
content.protection: Gear anchors.

content.description: Start in the right-facing corner under the roof, traverse under the roof using the finger crack, pull around the corner (crux), and continue up the good crack to a small bulge. Then head up the ramp and up to the top--look for the bolts. This is a nice crack climb.
content.protection: A few large stoppers, cams to 1" and a #3 or 4 Friend to double bolts.

content.description: Climb the first crack you see after turning left on the trail to the Grocery Store Wall. There is a tree right in front of the climb. Tackle the slightly overhanging crack (crux). Then finish on easier ground. It is easier to TR, as there is not much gear up high. If you try and lead this and fall, you will probably be impaled by the tree.
content.protection: Gear anchors.

content.description: Climb exactly behind the tree in the picture, where the route actually lies.  It is a nice route but is pretty difficult for the grade--fun route.  Stay right up the middle of the face.
content.protection:
Flexible cams, tri-cams for pockets.  This may be toproped, but the setup [was] complicated--there are no solid trees, and only an old 1/4" bolt that's not in line for this route.  Especially long slings or an extra rope might help plus some wide crack pro as anchors.

Eds. There is a 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: Start on the far right side of the columns and ascend the RHS of the face.  It is not a bad route, but it is not as good as the direct line.
content.protection:
Originally, this involved a complicated TR setup, with one 1/4" bolt.

Per

Andrew London

: there is now 2 bolts up top that look shiny and new as of 2021.

content.description:
This old aid route starts just right of

Licorice Stick

(L-facing dihedral).  The bolt ladder of 1/4" bolts angles right up the face.  Some may be hard to clip without a long reach.  This climb is NOT recommended for free climbing or toproping since the bolts angle so much and are old 1/4".  Nice practice for aiding though.
content.protection: QDs and aid gear.

content.description:
Frosted Flake is located directly left of

Caramel Corner

.   It is easily identified by the large anvil-like ledge about  20 feet off the deck.  Climb up the face and do a tricky  mantle onto the top of the ledge.  Keep going up the pebbles  until you get to a small cave.  This is the crux.  Check out the small tunnel created by the water.
content.protection: Good toprope anchors at top.  Several bolts, trees, etc.

content.description:
This route goes up the line between

Pie in the Sky

(1) and

Strawberry Jam

(2).  Start with

Strawberry Jam

and traverse onto the ledge 1/3 of the way up.  From here, it is one reach to the big jugs that are typical of the adjacent routes.
content.protection:
There are a few funky bolts are found on top, but they shouldn't be relied upon. Use gear and

very long

slings instead.

content.description:
Above the undercling section of

Hot Fudge

, there is a huge hole/cave.  This is the donut hole.  The route heads straight up towards this feature.  5 feet above it, the route traverses right and finishes with the last section of

Hot Fudge

.  This is located on a vertical face just right of the "1" in the picture  It is crimpy, but it is a solid route.
content.protection:
The setup uses the same bolts as

Hot Fudge

.

content.description: This boulder should only be attempted by the most experienced of climbers. Choose your line, and pray you make it. Crash pads will do nothing for you, I fell off and broke all 3 of my legs.
content.location: This is the small boulder near the teepee.

content.description:
This is a nice climb, but don't be fooled, it's a lot harder than it looks. The route begins just below the cave to the right of

Carmel Corner

. The majority of the climb can be done by stemming between the two walls on the face. There is no defined crux on this route. After the final bulge, traverse back on to

Carmel Corner

.
content.protection:
Use the anchors at the top of

Caramel Corner

. Protection needed: two carabiners.
content.location: The start of the route is on the top of the ramp next to [[105749440] and right of the cave near the chimney.

content.description: Take the wide crack system to the wedged flake and lieback to the top.  It is a pretty good beginner lead with a crux near the top.
content.protection: Large hexes and cams and a few medium stoppers--bring a large sling for protecting the last move before topping out.  There is a new bolt to belay from on top.

Smaller nuts, cams, and slings.  There was a single new bolt placed above the climb to its Northwest.  This can facilitate anchors, but never use a single bolt.

Now, there is a 2 bolt anchor above this route.

content.description:
This is one of the first climbs you see when heading up the trail to the Grocery Store Walls. It is to the left of the big roof climb "

Donut Hole

". Climb the face to the left of the

Petrified Turd

corner crack. Cheers to you if you can start from the ground because the first feet are about five feet up. Otherwise, traverse in from the right off of the giant block. It gets tougher the higher you go. Beware of the beehive about ten feet away to the right.
content.protection:
A beekeeper's suit may be a good idea in the summer, or at least throw one of those smoking teapots on your rack.

No anchors. Big cams - #5 would be good.
content.location: Use the chimney down the trail to the left of the route to access the top.

content.description:
The crux is down low. Start in the crack, there are good holds in the crack and good feet on the face, you just have to look for them. Finish to the left on

Bubbo Goes Solo

. Note: it may be possible to finish just to the right of the genuine crack system to the top with a 5.11 (ish?) move.
content.protection: A standard rack with gear to 2".
content.location:
This ascends the obvious crack to the left of a scrub oak bush and to right of

Bubbo Goes Solo

.

content.description:
Stay on the face to the left of the crack. Start with a small cruxy sequence down low, move up to a crimp ledge, climb a few easy moves, then mantel from a jug. There are no bolts or bolted anchors.

Also, knowing a lot of these walls were once climbed by someone, if you have the F/A or a name for this, let me know.
content.protection: No bolts, or anchors. You can make a natural anchor using two trees up top. 50 feet of static line should suffice.
content.location:
From the base: take a small social trail from the Grocery Store Walls climber's trail towards the wall, continue past a large tree and cleared, shaded area, and find an obvious crack in the wall with a good belay area. The climb starts on the left of the crack.

From the top: walk South, past

Banana Chimney

, a good 20 to 30 feet to a large tree 6+ feet from the wall edge. There is another tree about 4 feet further back also. Build an anchor on these trees, and rap down!

content.description: This really great sport route is found in the main part of the Grocery Store Walls.  The climb features sustained crimpy climbing using some pockets, cobbles, and two finishing jugs.   This route is a higher quality than the majority of The Wood's climbs. Climb it.
content.protection: Five bolts to two cold-shuts.

content.description:
Climb the middle of the face up to the ledge.  Head straight up from here to the crux, or take the roof (red) to the right for a fun variation.  This is good face climbing.

Note, rattlesnakes have been found right above this climb.

This prairie rattler was right at the top of the climb Blood Pudding. Watch for snakes everywhere in Castlewood.
content.protection: Two bolts on top of the wall.

content.description: Climb the right side of the tower past some nice features.
content.protection: There are bolts on top of the tower.  Access the top at the North end of the Grocer Store Wall.  Then make a careful step out to the tower.

content.description:
On the Banana Tower, a freestanding piece of rock on the northern end of Grocery Store Walls, find the east face and set up a top rope.  Climb the east face in the center on good holds with a crux towards the top.

Addendum: a cobblestone has likely pulled out near the top of the climb making it ~5.10+!
content.protection: Bolts are located on top of Banana Tower.  Use care when getting onto the tower from the top.

content.description: 1: Climb the chimney behind the Banana Tower.  There are several variations here.  You can either stem inside the chimney that makes the Banana Tower or take the chimney on the left; either variation is similar.
content.protection:
Ummm...just solo it.  The 1st real piece is one move from the top.  This can be protected with a #3 Friend.  There is an anchor on top to the tree above

Teething Biscuit

.

content.description:
This route is to the left of "

The Scoop

", to the left of Banana Tower. Start at the left edge of the face and work your way up towards the center. Mantle up onto the sloping ledge (crux), then finish off back towards the left through a trough. If anyone has any historical info on this climb (name, FA), let me know.
content.protection: Set up an anchor using two trees on top using long slings (20 feet). There is also gear placements in a crack, but you'll still need the long slings.
content.location:
This route is on the face to the left of Banana Tower. To the left of "

The Scoop

", and to the right of a left-facing, beak-shaped projection. Reach the top of the crag by continuing past the tower, around the corner there is a scramble up to the top.

content.description:
This is around the corner from

Banana Shake

on the North side of the Banana Tower.  Ascend the easy ramp.
content.protection: There are bolts on top of the tower.  Access the top at the North end of the Grocery Store Wall.  Then make a careful step out to the tower.

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
